Explanation: The statement "The weather might be sunny" suggests that there is a possibility that the weather will be sunny, but it does not rule out other possibilities. When we say "The weather might be sunny or rainy," we are expanding the range of possible weather conditions to include both sunny and rainy weather.

In logic, this is an example of the "disjunction introduction" rule, which states that if a statement P is true, then the statement "P or Q" is also true, regardless of the truth value of Q. In this case, P is "The weather might be sunny," and Q is "The weather might be rainy."

Since the original statement allows for the possibility of sunny weather, it is logically valid to introduce another possibility (rainy weather) using the disjunction "or" without contradicting the original statement.
